description: Dive into "Granada's Picture-Perfect Views Await" ‚Äî a handpicked list of places with quick notes, links, and essentials for fast trip planning and discovery.
title: Granada's Picture-Perfect Views Await

places.generalDescription: Mirador de San Nicol√°s is a bustling square situated on an elevated hilltop in Granada, offering stunning panoramic views of the Alhambra. It's renowned for its dramatic sunset vistas and is considered one of the best spots to admire the fortress from afar. The square is located in an old neighborhood and provides unobstructed views of the entire Alhambra, making it a must-visit location.

sources.snippet: The Mirador de San Nicolas is one of the most beautiful spots in Granada, and although visiting it during the day is also an unforgettable experience, at night it acquires a different, romantic and unique atmosphere. It is a great experience for couples, but also for groups of friends or even for solo travel (the kind you do to discover yourself). Some people dare to claim that this is the best viewpoint in Spain, we do not go that far, but if we confirm that the views from this magnificent cliff cover almost all of Granada, at night, the illuminated views of the city have an air that borders on fantasy.
sources.shortName: What to see in Granada at night: your 7 best choices

sources.snippet: Rounding out our lineup of the best views of Granada is a small, nondescript viewing point you might come across on your way up to the Alhambra. Granada's tourism board refers to this spot, located near the parking lot along Avenida Santa Mar√≠a de la Alhambra, as the " Mirador de Granada." It's a relatively quiet, low-key place where you can get some of the best views of the city and its gorgeous natural surroundings. It's an especially convenient option if you're exploring Granada by car.
sources.shortName: 5 Best Views of Granada That Will Take Your Breath Away

sources.snippet: It is a basic among the basics of the best places in Granada to photograph the Alhambra. There is no tourist or resident who doesn‚Äôt know the spectacular panorama offered by this viewpoint located in the heart of Albaic√≠n that lets you see the Alhambra with Sierra Nevada in the background. Surely it will be difficult for you to find a small gap among all the curious who come to take the best photograph of Granada, but we assure you that it will be very worthwhile.
sources.shortName: 12 Great photo spots in Granada üì∏, What's your favorite?

sources.snippet: One of the best things to do in Granada, Spain, the Mirador de San Nicolas has arguably the best views of the Alhambra in the whole city. In a word, this viewpoint is incredible. When you go up to Plaza de San Nicolas (I recommend going at sunset, it adds to the experience), not only will you be surrounded by beautiful music and merchants, but you‚Äôll also get an unreal view of the Alhambra Palace, the city, and the Sierra Nevada Mountains.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain (By a Former Tour Guide)

sources.snippet: Mirador San Nicol√°sGranada, SpainPeople come here for the best views of Granada and it‚Äôs easy to see why ‚Äì located atop a hill in Albayzin, this spot looks at the Alhambra as well as the twinkling lights and roofs of the city below. Come around 4:45pm to reseed yourself a spot, since it can get pretty crowded. You‚Äôll see locals hanging out here, as well as travelers and gypsy musicians singing and playing guitar.
sources.shortName: 10 Must See Spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: The most known and popular photography spot in Granada ‚Äì Mirador St Nicholas is located on the opposite hill to Alhambra, giving you a chance to capture this stunning monument in its full glory. Just a word of warning ‚Äì it is very popular and therefore very busy. You may encounter big crowds as you get there and might have to wait a while to get your turn to take a photo.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Photography Locations in Granada: Expert Tips

sources.snippet: Mirador de San Nicolas is located in the historical neighborhood of the Albaycin, and this is another great spot to watch the sunrise and sunset. The best views of the Alhambra are seen from here, and the walk is an easy one. Alexis Walker is a CEA MOJO Lite Content Contributor who studied abroad in Granada, Spain, during the Spring 2020 semester.
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: The first option for photographing the Alhambra is easily the most popular. However, after spending a few hours there photographing the site, I can certainly see why. This viewpoint, located a short 15 minute walk from the centre of town affords the visitor an excellent panoramic view of the Alhambra and the surrounding mountains.
sources.shortName: Best Places in Granada to Photograph the Alhambra

sources.snippet: Mirador San Nicol√°s is one of those places that‚Äôs Instagrammable from several angles. One of those angles is from the bottom and another is from overlooking the gorgeous Alhambra. Mirador is a must-do attraction while in Granada for several reasons and one of them is its absolutely charming view.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Instagrammable Places in Granada

sources.snippet: The most iconic view of the Alhambra can be seen from the viewpoint of San Nicolas. This is the most prominent viewpoint in the city and the one preferred by tourists visiting Granada. It's possible to see groups of friends playing flamenco and craft vendors in the vicinity.
sources.shortName: Viewpoints in Granada - Top viewpoints in Granada

sources.snippet: Granada is a city at the foot of the famous Sierra Nevada mountains where you can see the highest peak in the Iberian Peninsula and in mainland Spain. And, quite often, walking around Granada means hiking uphill or downhill. I hope you are ready for that!
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: If you ask anyone in Granada for things to do, they‚Äôll tell you to head to Mirador San Nicolas just before sunset. Here you‚Äôll find gorgeous panoramic views of the city of Granada and the Alhambra. The view is great, amazing in fact.
sources.shortName: Where to Get the Best Alhambra Views and Photos in 2019

sources.snippet: Speaking of San Nicholas, here is where you‚Äôll find the perfect panoramic view of La Alhambra. It‚Äôs framed perfectly with the snow-capped Sierra Nevada in the back and the city at its feet.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots in Granada

sources.snippet:
The famous viewpoint in Granada offers stunning views of the Alcazar and the Sierra Nevada, 
near the Church of St. Nicholas in the Albaicin quarter.
sources.shortName: The Most Beautiful Places and Romantic Sights of Granada
20 Best Things To Do
13 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain

places.name: Mirador de San Nicol√°s

reviews.text: It's a solid twenty minute walk uphill to get to the viewpoint, but you are a rewarded with a wonderful view of the Alhambra and the Sierra Nevada mountains. The view is prettier at sunset, but the crowds are also thicker. Nice to see the sunset and then go down to the river and walk alongside it back into town at night.

A simple Muslim church with gentle simplicity, solemnity, and wonder. It makes me calm my heart to have a little peace and a special invisible connection.
It's not a simple church but also a real spirit, the testimony of time of history.

The ticket is 3¬£ but you get the gorgeous view on the top of the church ‚õ™Ô∏è
I enjoy it very much
Highly recommended!

It's a good location to view Alhambra, also very busy at evening, everyone has been told this is the best spot to view Alhambra when the lights are on. It becomes more popular because of the South Korean TV romance drama, you can see a lot of East Asian.

It's not a long walk uphill from the busy street, maybe 15 minutes if you are a walker, but it will be challenging if you walk during the day when it is hot. The view is worthy. And it's free.

places.address: Plaza Mirador de San Nicol√°s, 2, Albaic√≠n, 18010 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Nestled atop the picturesque Sabika hill, the Alhambra stands as a breathtaking testament to Granada's rich history and architectural splendor. This medieval complex, originally constructed in the 13th century by the Nasrid dynasty, showcases an exquisite blend of Islamic artistry and Christian influences following its conquest in 1492. Visitors are captivated by its intricately carved throne rooms, serene cloistered courtyards adorned with fountains, and stunning mosaic tilework that reflects Granada‚Äôs iconic style.

sources.snippet: While the dense, steep cliffside beneath the Alhambra might look impossible to tackle, it does, in fact, provide an off-piste route up to the great fort. The path ‚Äì for which a sturdy pair of trainers is required ‚Äì is accessed by crossing the bridge to the right at the end of the Paseo de los Tristes and heading up Camino Fuente del Avellano. After a few minutes, a sharp right off this path zigzags up through the dense woodland and fauna.
sources.shortName: 5 Beautiful Spots In Granada Even Locals Don't Know About

sources.snippet: AlhambraGranada, SpainUnless you live under a rock larger than the building blocks of the Alhambra, you know this is the most famous historical spot of Granada (and the world). In a nutshell, the Alhambra was originally constructed as a small fortress in 889AD until the Moorish emir really upped its game in the 13th century. Seemingly simple from the outside, the Alhambra is elaborate and resplendent on the inside and is an absolute must-see in Granada.
sources.shortName: 10 Must See Spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: Alhambra is the crowning glory of Granada and in a lot of cases the sole reason why people venture to this Andalusian city. The whole Alhambra complex consists of a few major landmarks ‚Äì Palacio Nazaries, Palacio de Carlos V, Generalife Gardens and Alcazaba. You will need probably a full day to explore the whole complex and the gardens, and if you want a good chance for the best photos, aim to get the first tickets available.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Photography Locations in Granada: Expert Tips

sources.snippet: The Alhambra stands majestically on a fortified hilltop with the snow-peaked Sierra Nevada Mountains as a backdrop. An absolute must-see attraction in Granada, this UNESCO-listed World Heritage Site was the residence of the Moorish rulers of the Nasrid Dynasty for 250 glorious years, from the 13th to the 15th centuries. The complex of palaces was the Moors' last stronghold in Spain.
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Granada

sources.snippet: As Spain's most popular tourist attraction, it's no surprise that the Alhambra tops this list of the best places to see the sunset in Granada. You can't go wrong with any of the jawdroppingly beautiful views from the structure. However, for the absolute best views at sunset, head to the Alcazaba fortress and climb the narrow stairs to the old watchtower ( Torre de la Vela).
sources.shortName: 7 Spectacular Places to Watch the Sunset in Granada You Need to See

sources.snippet: Perhaps the most famous thing to do in Granada, Spain, the Alhambra Palace is the crown jewel of Andalusia and one of the best examples of Moorish architecture. What was once a small fortress, the original Alhambra Palace was constructed on top of Roman fortifications in 889 AD. It was then re-built to its current iteration by the Moors in the 13th century.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain (By a Former Tour Guide)
Best 2 Days in Granada Itinerary 2024

sources.snippet: Made up of 29 towers, seven gates and a 2,000m wall, La Alhambra is chock-full of insta-worthy shots. Highlights of this incredible Moorish palace such as The Hall of Sisters, Palace of Charles V and most famously, The Court of Lions will leave you (and your followers!) speechless.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots in Granada

sources.snippet: One of Spain's top tourist attractions, the stunning Alhambra Palace sits on top of a hill surrounded by forest while overlooking the city below. It was built by Moorish king Mohammed ben Al-Ahmar in the 11th century when the area was ruled by Muslims from North Africa.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things To Do

sources.snippet: Of course, we have to mention the one and only Alhambra, one of the biggest reasons why people decide to take the trip to Granada in the first place. Along with Generalife, Alhambra is one of the most picturesque places of the city and definitely worthy of a visit.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Instagrammable Places in Granada

sources.snippet: Mirador de San Nicolas is located in the Albaicin neighborhood directly across the valley for the Alhambra. The neighborhood is beautiful and worth a tour around. I let myself get lost in the alleys on my way back down and was not disappointed.
sources.shortName: Granada's Best Sunset Spots

sources.snippet: The Alhambra is a must-see in all of Granada, and when you take your tour, be sure to go to the Alcazaba watchtower. Here, you can get one of the best and most central views of Granada.
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Granada, Spain
13 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain

places.name: Alhambra

reviews.text: The visit is worth all the money of the entrance ticket. You can choose to tour with or without a guide. Either way, it is all breathtakingly beautiful. The architecture blends perfectly with the surrounding natural landscape. The colors, richness and artistic details are incredible. A must see at least once in a lifetime.

Simply the most beautiful place I've ever been.  Literally built over centuries, the size and scope is just unbelievable that it was from materials brought from all over and carried up the mountainside in Granada Spain.
I recommend taking a bus or taxi up to the entrance as you will walk over 100 steps and walk around 1-3 miles to try to see everything.  The hike up to the Alhambra is a workout on its own!  It's was worth it but I did take a bus back down once I was done.
I recommend taking a trip here during your lifetime, you won't regret it!

First of all, if you want to visit this magnificent palace, you'll need a full day. Don't forget to buy your tickets online in advance. Bring your passports with you when you visit. As I said, it's a magnificent palace. The gardens, pools, buildings, and trees are magnificent in every inch. Entry times for certain areas are listed on your ticket, so don't miss out.

places.address: C. Real de la Alhambra, s/n, Centro, 18009 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Catedral de Granada is a lavish Renaissance cathedral known for its gold-and-white interior and stained-glass domed chapel. Construction began in 1518, incorporating Gothic, Renaissance, and Baroque styles over the course of 180 years. The facade was largely designed by Alonso Cano, introducing Baroque features in 1652.

sources.snippet: Catedral de GranadaGranada, SpainLocated in the heart of Granada, the cathedral is absolutely gorgeous inside and out. Enter through the little square and stick to the right. You‚Äôll see marvelous paintings, carvings and organs as well as an elaborate display of figures representing historical events from the area.
sources.shortName: 10 Must See Spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: This magical-looking cathedral was built by the one and only Queen Isabella and it‚Äôs the 4th largest cathedral in the world. The building itself is known as the masterpiece of Spanish Renaissance - it features an impressive exterior as well as interior with a grand altar and several chapels.
sources.shortName: 10 Most Instagrammable Places in Granada

sources.snippet: Built by none other than Queen Isabella is a total jaw-dropper and perfect for the gram. Complete with many chapels varying in size and age, it‚Äôs the fourth largest cathedral in the world.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots in Granada

places.name: Catedral de Granada

reviews.text:
The Cathedral of Granada is an amazing place to visit. Right in the center of the city, the building is huge and beautiful, with impressive architecture that mixes Renaissance and Baroque styles.

When you walk inside, you're greeted by tall white columns, golden decorations, and colorful stained-glass windows. Everything feels grand and peaceful at the same time. Each chapel inside has its own special artwork and history, making it really interesting to explore.

The Cathedral was built on the site of an old mosque, so it also tells the story of Granada's history and culture after the Reconquista. Right next to it, the Royal Chapel is also worth seeing-this is where Queen Isabella and King Ferdinand are buried.

It's a good idea to spend at least an hour here and maybe use an audio guide to learn more about the details. Going early in the day is best if you want to enjoy it without the crowds.

Overall, the Cathedral of Granada is a beautiful and important place that you should definitely visit when in the city.

Wow! Wow! Wow!
Ridiculously beautiful. I have seen lots of castles and cathedrals in Europe and this one just seemed very special. We had a wonderful tour with our guide Manuel, and he knew so much about the cathedral, but it was also fascinating because it spans architectural styles (mostly Renaissance) since it took some time for it to be built. A special note is the organ, which is magnificently beautiful. And the white stonework shines as a backdrop to all of the gilded art...it was really like visiting a museum! Again, one of the most impressive cathedrals I have ever had the privilege to tour. Check out these photos! It's just dripping with beauty, even though some of it is over the top architecturally. But‚Ä¶ It's a cathedral, it's supposed to be full of beauty and elegance to celebrate this earth and the heavens.
Lovely historic building, very well maintained. Audio tours available in multiple languages on your own mobile device. Lots of photo opportunities if you love architecture

places.address: Pl. de las Pasiegas, s/n, Centro, 18001 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: The Generalife, an ancient Muslim palace, is renowned for its exquisite ornamental gardens that feature serene pools, charming courtyards, and a riot of vibrant blooms. When visiting Granada, it's essential to dedicate at least three to four hours to explore this stunning complex. If time allows, you can easily spend an entire day marveling at the intricate Moorish architecture found throughout both the Alhambra and Generalife.

sources.snippet: In stark contrast to the Nasrid Palace with its elaborate ornamental decorations on walls and perfect symmetry anywhere you look, Generalife can seem a little plain and simple, but that certainly doesn‚Äôt take away anything from its beauty. The gardens were designed as a relaxation place for the sultans and kings, and have undergone a lot of design and structural changes. The newest part of the gardens is outside the main Palace, right by the entrance ‚Äì Jardines Nuevos.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Photography Locations in Granada: Expert Tips

sources.snippet: GeneralifeGranada, SpainThe Generalife is an absolute treat for the outdoor enthusiast/ your inner kid. Once the emir‚Äôs summer residence, this part of the Alhambra is covered in lush greenery, flowers, orange trees and tiny streams run through. The only thing that would have made me feel more like Alice in Wonderland would have been finding a white tabbing to chase.
sources.shortName: 10 Must See Spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: And finally, we could not leave behind the most important place in Granada and one of the most beautiful in the world, the Alhambra. Undoubtedly, the best place to take your camera, as you will not lack rooms, patios, gardens and ideal corners to immortalize. A more than obligatory site to add to this list of Instagrammable places in Granada, don‚Äôt you think?
sources.shortName: 12 Great photo spots in Granada üì∏, What's your favorite?

sources.snippet: If you‚Äôre looking for a few snaps of some of the most gorgeous gardens ever, Generalife is the place to be. The garden was built in the 13th century, but unfortunately, the garden you see today has been completely altered and rebuilt. Nevertheless, it‚Äôs an excellent place to take some snaps for the gram!
sources.shortName: 10 Most Instagrammable Places in Granada

sources.snippet: The most emblematic place of the city, one of the most visited monuments in Spain and Europe and also one of the most beautiful places you will ever visit. Any corner of the Alhambra and the Generalife is worthy of a photo. The gardens are spectacular, not to mention these two palaces and their patios.
sources.shortName: ‚ñ∑The 7 Most Photogenic Places of the city of Granada
What To Do & See in Granada Spain: It's Not Just the Alhambra

sources.snippet: This gaudy Moorish palace was essentially the summer party pad of the Nasrid rulers. Along with stellar views of the city, it‚Äôs also complete with all the gardens, courtyards and unbelievable vistas you‚Äôd expect.
sources.shortName: The 7 Most Instagrammable Spots in Granada

sources.snippet: The Generalife is a little bit apart from the rest of the Palaces. Nice gardens lead you up to the white building with the typical patio with a little pond and flowers.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographer's Guide to Granada

places.name: Generalife

reviews.text: Wonderful gardens! Almost as good as the Nasrid Palaces. Don't skip this on your visit to the Alhambra. The way the gardeners have actively managed the trees and hedges to grow into walls and arches is magnificent and each pool with its Lilly pads, alage and frongs were beautiful. The way that the Moors were able to manage the temperature so well with use of shade, plants and water shows how clever they were. Truly a fantastic visit!

Beautiful gardens with stunning views and a lovely scent from the flowers. The gardens are well kept, safe to walk or stroll a pram, and there is one drinking fountain to top up your water bottle on a hot day. Some steps are very deep and hard to climb if you have difficulties, but there are plenty of seats to sit and enjoy if preferred.

The Generalife is a true oasis of peace and beauty within the Alhambra. üå∫‚ú® Walking through these historic gardens felt like stepping into a living painting - vibrant flowers, perfectly manicured hedges, and the gentle sound of fountains and flowing water all around. üíß

The views over Granada and the surrounding mountains are breathtaking, especially at sunset, when the whole landscape glows. üåÑ Each corner has its own charm, from the tranquil courtyards to the elegant archways framing perfect photo spots. üì∏

It's the ideal place to slow down, breathe, and soak up centuries of history and artistry, away from the busier parts of the Alhambra. A must-visit for anyone who loves gardens, architecture, and a touch of magic. üåü

places.generalDescription: Mirador de San Crist√≥bal is a stone observation point in Granada that offers stunning panoramic views of the city. It is wheelchair accessible and provides a less crowded alternative to other viewpoints. From here, visitors can see the old city wall and landmarks such as the Alhambra, cathedral, Palace of Dar al-Horra, and Convent of Santa Isabel la Catolica. The location also allows for a picturesque view of Granada from the west, framed by the Sierra Nevada mountain.

sources.snippet: We started our guide with a viewpoint and ended it with another equally beautiful viewpoint, also located in the upper part of the Albaic√≠n. In addition to offering magnificent views of the Alhambra, Sierra Nevada and almost the entire city of Granada, it is located next to the church of San Cristobal, another tourist attraction that we recommend you visit. As a differentiating point, it is also one of the few places that offer a privileged view of the great canvas of the old Zir√≠ wall, also located in the Albaic√≠n neighborhood.
sources.shortName: What to see in Granada at night: your 7 best choices

sources.snippet: This viewpoint in the highest part of the Albaicin offers a panoramic view of the Alhambra and the surrounding monuments, as well as a large part of the 11th century Zirid wall. From here you can also admire the Cathedral, the Palace of Dal al Horra, and the church of San Cristobal. To access this viewpoint you need to cross the Puerta de Elvira and climb the stairs of the Cuesta de San Cristobal.
sources.shortName: Viewpoints in Granada - Top viewpoints in Granada

sources.snippet: This less-popular yet equally impressive viewpoint is much quieter than Mirador de San Nicol√°s, and you won't be fighting off nearly as many crowds. The Mirador de San Crist√≥bal, located just west of the Albayz√≠n, offers a different, more unique view of the sunset in Granada. It's a bit of a hike, but well worth the effort.
sources.shortName: 7 Spectacular Places to Watch the Sunset in Granada You Need to See

places.name: Mirador de San Crist√≥bal

reviews.text: The climb up to the viewpoint is a blast. Views are worth every drop of sweat üòÖ

This is one of the stops if you use the Granada Tour Bus.

The view is amazing, you can see for miles on end!  The area was quiet when we visited early in the morning.  I would think it gets busier during sunset.

We walked to Mirador de San Nicolas from here to catch the sunset and get an evening view of the Alhambra.
A peaceful viewpoint with stunning views of the Alhambra, Granada, and Sierra Nevada. Less crowded than San Nicol√°s, offering a more local and authentic experience. Great spot for sunset photos.

places.address: Ctra. de Murcia, 47, Albaic√≠n, 18010 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Nestled within the enchanting Alhambra, the Nasrid Palaces are a stunning testament to Moorish architecture and history. Visitors can wander through opulent courtyards, grand reception halls, and regal quarters that showcase intricate designs and exquisite craftsmanship. The palaces offer a captivating glimpse into the past with their unique inscriptions, vibrant painted decorations, and an array of beautiful antiques.

sources.snippet: Alhambra is arguably the most famous tourist attraction in Granada, Andalusia, and possibly in Spain. It is a massive fortress on a hill in Granada. Inside the citadel, there are multiple palaces and residences built for kings, expansive gardens, and other infrastructure made for Alhambra to be a self-contained city.
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: The Nasrid Palace is the main reason for most of the people to visit the Alhambra. Most of the pictures you have seen might have been from there. The patios of the palace have some really beautiful arabesques and ornamentation and you feel like in a Moroccan palace.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographer's Guide to Granada

places.name: Nasrid Palaces

reviews.text:
without question, the city's crown jewel - a Moorish palace and fortress with grand archways, delicate mosaics, and views that make you stop mid-step. Give yourself at least 3‚Äì4 hours to explore it properly. Wear your comfiest shoes, because you'll be doing plenty of walking, plus a few stair climbs that are totally worth it for the views.

Make sure to.biy tickets ahead of time.

Amazing architecture, every corner is detailed, so much beauty, if it's not to crowdy wonder around and dream away . Book your tickets at least 1 week before best to visit early in the morning or late afternoon

So so lovely. Visited on a lovely hot day. We bought tickets in advance. Make sure you get there for the time stated on your ticket. You may have to wait in a queue but if your not in the queue for your time you may not get in. MAKE SURE YOU TAKE YOUR PASSPORT!   No entry without. Would highly recommend you pay for a guide to explain what your looking at. It's lovely, but will mean more with an explanation. It's amazing to see the restoration that has taken place on the site. There a board that shows you what it looked like in the 1920's. Not and expensive visit. A day well spent.

places.address: C. Real de la Alhambra, s/n, Centro, 18009 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Carmen de los M√°rtires is a stunning 19th-century estate that invites visitors to explore its beautifully landscaped gardens, complete with enchanting statues and fountains. Spanning seven hectares on the picturesque Sabika hill, adjacent to the iconic Alhambra, this park features diverse areas such as a French Baroque garden centered around a grand pond with a Neptune statue, and the Palm Garden adorned with an impressive three-tiered fountain.

sources.snippet: In case you still did not know the origins of Granada‚Äôs Carmenes, these were a typical type of house, rustic and fenced, that had a garden, green space, orchard and fountain or pool. Its origin is Nasrid, but today we still have some, such as the Carmen de los M√°rtires, the best known and the largest in the entire city. It is located within the Alhambra enclosure and its entrance is free, so you can explore it freely while taking pictures of its beautiful gardens, its pond and its views of Granada.
sources.shortName: 12 Great photo spots in Granada üì∏, What's your favorite?

sources.snippet: Carmen de los Martires is a beautiful secluded garden with a mansion and Nasrid orchards, a short distance from the Alhambra. The name ‚ÄòCarmen‚Äô is actually used for a type of house native to Granada, which normally consists of an orchard, green space annex, and garden. They are many of these in Granada, some smaller and others, like Carmen de Los Martires, a lot more impressive.
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Photography Locations in Granada: Expert Tips

sources.snippet: Surprisingly, some of the best views of the sunset in Granada come from ground level. Carmen de los Martires is proof that you don't need to hike up to a  mirador to catch amazing views. This peaceful little home within the Alhambra offers a quiet courtyard and sweeping views of the valley below.
sources.shortName: 7 Spectacular Places to Watch the Sunset in Granada You Need to See

sources.snippet: Of course we absolutely have to include one of Granada‚Äôs most romantic destinations!. Carmen de los Martires is a perfect place to take a long walk and reflect, all while snapping some amazing photos of peacocks!
sources.shortName: 10 Most Instagrammable Places in Granada

sources.snippet: Carmen is a word you will stumble upon frequently when searching for something on Google Maps in Granada. No, Carmen in this case is not a woman. The name actually comes from the Arabic karm which means vines.
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet:
This garden by the Alhambra is an ideal romantic oasis with small ponds, leafy paths, 
and stunning views around the historic mansion.
sources.shortName: The Most Beautiful Places and Romantic Sights of Granada

places.name: Carmen de los M√°rtires

reviews.text: A beautiful park! Has lot to explore: fountains, landscaped gardens etc. It is located not too far from the Alhambra exit but surprisingly with very few visitors. A real hidden gem of Granada. The highlight is to see the peacocks spreading their feathers! You can sit in the bench and enjoy the panoramic view the Granada and Sierra Nevada mountains in quiet! A not to be missed place if you are visiting this city.

A beautiful garden perfect for an evening stroll. Located close to the Alhambra entrance/exit, and had surprisingly few visitors even on a weekend evening. I suppose it is a lovely little hidden gem at least for tourists. The gardens are reasonably well maintained for a free tourist attraction. There are fountains, engraved plaques with Spanish poetry, a small building (part of a palace perhaps) to marvel at, as well as bathrooms and potable water near said building. Undoubtedly, one of the highlights were the peacocks strolling about. Not much signage in English, or at all, but there was some information displayed about the origins of this park (as a tribute to the Christian martyrs capture under Islamic rule and invasions).
A beautiful place for a nice stroll. The gardens are well maintained. We enjoyed the gardens but didn't go inside the building itself. The building was closed. It's worth the trip.

places.address: P.¬∫ de los M√°rtires, s/n, Centro, 18009 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Saint Michael Viewpoint, also known as Mirador de San Miguel, is a popular destination in Granada offering breathtaking panoramic views of the city and the Alhambra. Located at Ermita de San Miguel Alto, it requires a bit of effort to reach as visitors need to climb up a small mountain. The viewpoint provides stunning photographic opportunities and is situated in a more rural area beyond the narrow streets of The Albaicin.

sources.snippet: As its name suggests, it's the highest viewpoint in Granada. It offers panoramic views of the Alhambra and the Generalife, the Albaicin neighborhood, Sacromonte, Sierra Nevada, and Sierra Elvira. The San Miguel Alto Hermitage is located here as well and is the destination of a pilgrimage by the locals on September 29th.
sources.shortName: Viewpoints in Granada - Top viewpoints in Granada
Granada's Best Sunset Spots

places.name: San Miguel Alto viewpoint

reviews.text:
If you climb up for about 15 minutes from the Nicolas viewpoint, you will arrive at this place where you can see a beautiful sunset. It is said that locals often use this as a dating course.

The best place to see the Alhambra Palace and the open view and sunset

One of the best viewpoints in Granada! San Miguel Alto offers breathtaking panoramic views of the Alhambra, Sierra Nevada, and the entire city. A peaceful spot, especially at sunset. The walk up is steep, but the view is absolutely worth it!
Beautiful view...would recommend to everyone..lots of free parking..

places.address: Cam. del Sacromonte, s/n, Albaic√≠n, 18010 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: The Royal Chapel of Granada, built in the 1500s, is a mausoleum for Catholic royalty and also serves as a museum. It is a popular tourist attraction located next to the Granada Cathedral. The chapel is famous for being the burial place of Isabella and Ferdinand II, two powerful Catholic Monarchs who completed the reconquering of Spain from the Moors. The beautiful tomb made from alabaster was designed by Italian sculptor Domenico Fancelli.

sources.snippet: Visiting the Granada Cathedral and Royal Chapel are two of the most architecturally relevant things to do in Granada. The Granada Cathedral is a Roman Catholic structure that was built on top of Granada‚Äôs primary mosque after the fall of the Nasrid dynasty. The cathedral took over 180 years to build with the foundations having been laid between 1523 and 1529.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain (By a Former Tour Guide)

sources.snippet: Located in the heart of Granada city is the lavish cathedral ‚Äì Catedral de Granada. Built in the 16th century, this Renaissance cathedral is an impressive sight to see in Granada. With its gold-and-white interior, massive dome, and many chapels it tells a story about the city‚Äôs history throughout centuries.
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain
What To Do & See in Granada Spain: It's Not Just the Alhambra

places.name: Royal Chapel of Granada

reviews.text: This chatolic Roman church with rectanglar building is amazing. The architecture of building is Renaissance Baroque. Every meter you walk you will find one historical artistic item, I was shocked himw many items is there. You need to buy ticket 5 ‚Ç¨,the kids under 12 are free. There is some audio guide in entrance which include in your ticket.Its really helpful.

We were on a very long cruise from Venice to Portugal on NCL last year.  One of the stops was the port for Granada.  We took the cruise bus RT to Granada and self guided using Google maps and my research.  It was easy to find the major historic sites.  After looking at the cathedral, we went to the Royal Chapel where kings were buried.

It is a beautiful building, in and out, if you are in town and since it is well located, is a place to visit, even if you are not religious, just to thinks how building like those where created is a marvellous

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Granada, the Bas√≠lica de San Juan de Dios is a breathtaking example of 18th-century Baroque architecture that simply cannot be missed. Constructed between 1737 and 1759, this magnificent basilica dazzles with its opulent gold and silver embellishments that adorn nearly every inch of its interior.

sources.snippet: Amid the beautiful medieval Islamic art and architecture, Granada's masterpiece of Baroque often goes unnoticed. The Bas√≠lica San Juan de Dios immerses visitors into a fantasy of dazzling 18th-century decor. Intricate gilded carvings adorn almost every corner of the domed ceiling, walls, and side altars and frame the monumental paintings.
sources.shortName: 14 Top-Rated Tourist Attractions in Granada

sources.snippet: Bas√≠lica de San Juan de Dios is a true hidden gem in Granada. I am definitely not one of those people who always have to visit churches and cathedrals wherever I go, however, sometimes it is worth it and this is one of those times. This 18th-century Baroque basilica is simply breathtaking.
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain

places.name: Bas√≠lica de San Juan de Dios

reviews.text:
You definitely don't want to miss this treasure.
Exquisite, splendid, unique, with very easy to use audioguide.
The visit takes about 40-60 minutes, every part of this basilica brings surprises. Prepare to-be astonished.
Recommended to book in advance.

The first word that codes to mind is GOLD. Everywhere you look, you see gold. Besides that, everything is so detailed. You can download an app to listen to an audioguide or to read about the history so it is smart to take headphones. There is also a place where you can put on a VR and use that to watch a short movie. It made me a bit nausious but it was a nice touch.

The Bas√≠lica de San Juan de Dios is one of the most breathtaking Baroque churches I have ever visited. From the moment you step inside you are completely surrounded by golden altarpieces intricate carvings and an overwhelming sense of splendor that feels like stepping into another world.

The highlight is without doubt the main altarpiece a dazzling wall of gold angels and saints that dominates the sanctuary. The combination of sculpture painting and architecture is so rich and detailed that you can spend hours just admiring it. The dome and ceiling frescoes add even more beauty pulling your eyes upward as if heaven itself is opening above.

This basilica is not only about art it is also about devotion. The relics of St John of God the founder of the Hospitaller Order and patron saint of the sick are kept here. Knowing his history of service and charity adds great spiritual meaning to the place.

The church is not very large but every corner is filled with treasures silver reliquaries side chapels dedicated to saints and countless Baroque details. If you love history art or simply want to feel the richness of Granadas religious heritage this place is an absolute must.

Tip Take your time inside. The lighting changes during the day and every glance reveals something new you did not notice before.

places.address: C/ San Juan de Dios, 17, Centro, 18001 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Nestled in the heart of Granada, the Monasterio de San Jer√≥nimo is a stunning example of Renaissance architecture that dates back to 1504. Founded by the Catholic Monarchs Isabella and Ferdinand during the final stages of the Reconquista, this royal monastery showcases an exquisite blend of Gothic and Renaissance styles. Visitors are greeted by its impressive two-tiered cloisters and intricately decorated altars that reflect Granada's rich religious heritage.

sources.snippet: Opened in 1504 and built in a Renaissance style, the Monasterio de San Jeronimo is a Roman Catholic monastery founded by Catholic Monarchs Isabella I of Castile and Ferdinand II of Aragon. It was built during the last stage of the Reconquista and all the stones used during construction were salvaged from the Arab gate of Elvira. The monastery‚Äôs first courtyard has 36 arches with shields and the initials of kings and other prominent people whereas the second courtyard has arches in a traditionally Gothic style.
sources.shortName: 20 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain (By a Former Tour Guide)

sources.snippet: Monasterio de San Jer√≥nimo is a 16th-century monastery located in the heart of the Old Town of Granada. From the outside you won‚Äôt see anything special, however, the inside hides a lavishly decorated Renaissance-style interior. It is definitely worth a visit!
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain
What To Do & See in Granada Spain: It's Not Just the Alhambra
13 Best Things to Do in Granada, Spain

places.name: Monasterio de San Jer√≥nimo, Granada

reviews.text: This is such a pretty place! The courtyard full of orange and lemon trees was my favorite, but the simple, white rooms had their own beauty too. The chapel, by contrast, was very elaborate and decorated with lots of color everywhere; the ceiling was especially beautiful. We were privileged to be able to witness preparations for the Semana Santa processions, a truly special cultural experience. Also, the altar was adorned with fresh flower bouquets. So glad I got to see this!

Must to go! You can feel the history and great culture and arts from medieval time. The church looks amazing and gorgeous. Interesting to see that these monasteries in Granada have orange trees (also in Cathedral). I don't know the reason why and I don't think that audio guidance explained it.
For the audio guide I recommend to bring ear phones so you respect the place.

An impressive structure. Full with relics, paintings and statues. It was disappointing that it looks rundown. Having such cultural, historical and religious richness deserves pristine restoration. I hope on my next visit it will look better cared for.

places.address: C. Rector L√≥pez Arg√ºeta, 9, Centro, 18001 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Paseo de los Tristes, or the Promenade of the Sad Ones, is a charming and vibrant walkway in Granada that beautifully captures the essence of this historic city. Nestled alongside the River Darro, it meanders between two picturesque bridges‚Äîthe Moorish Las Chirimias and El Aljibillo‚Äîoffering stunning views of the iconic Alhambra.

sources.snippet: The Paseo de los Tristes follows part of the R√≠o Darro through Granada and is lined with numerous restaurants with beautiful outdoor seating. This is where you‚Äôll want to go for a special evening in Granada and the best part is that if you look up from your meal, you‚Äôll be looking straight up at the Alhambra. My personal recommendation is Restaurante Ruta del Azafran, which is the first restaurant you come across if approaching from the centre of the city.
sources.shortName: Where to Get the Best Alhambra Views and Photos in 2019

sources.snippet: Paseo de los tristesGranada, SpainTo be totally honest, I don‚Äôt see how you can walk around here and be sad (triste) ‚Äì it‚Äôs gorgeous even on tee coldest of winter days. Stroll by the river and look to your right at the narrow streets of Albaic√≠n leading uphill. You‚Äôll find a few restaurants and shops lining up this area, so stop, grab a bite and enjoy the moment.
sources.shortName: 10 Must See Spots in Granada, Spain

sources.snippet: It is one of the best known, touristy streets and probably the most beautiful street in Granada. Cobbled street, on the Darro River and located on the slope of the Alhambra. So the Paseo de los Tristes becomes one of the most photogenic places in Granada.
sources.shortName: 12 Great photo spots in Granada üì∏, What's your favorite?

sources.snippet: Paseo de Los Tristes is a square stretching at the feet of Alhambra, right next to Darro river. It is lined with restaurant terraces offering you a chance to enjoy tapas with some pretty spectacular views. Paseo de Los Tristes: Location
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Photography Locations in Granada: Expert Tips

sources.snippet:
Just below the Alhambra, this place is surrounded by historical buildings and natural beauty, 
with several romantic terraces along the River Darro.
sources.shortName: The Most Beautiful Places and Romantic Sights of Granada

places.name: P.¬∫ de los Tristes

reviews.text: Great place to take stroll with amazing views and also many restaurants options. Very busy! Watch out for car!!
Such a lovely park! And the Alhambra view is amazing
Historical site in front of Alhambra city! Great environment and beautiful place to eat!

places.generalDescription: Nestled just outside Granada's Old Town, the Monasterio de Nuestra Se√±ora de la Asunci√≥n 'La Cartuja' is a hidden gem that transports visitors to a realm of opulence and artistry. This 16th-century Carthusian monastery, with its unassuming sand-colored exterior, conceals an interior bursting with Baroque splendor. As you step inside, prepare to be mesmerized by the lavish golden details and vibrant marbles that adorn every corner.

sources.snippet: Monasterio de la Cartuja de Granada is a place with indescribable beauty. The plain grayish outside walls hide some of the most beautiful things you will ever see!. Located just on the outskirts of Granada‚Äôs Old Town (you can get there by bus or taxi), this monastery is a must-see place in Granada!
sources.shortName: 19 best Instagram photo spots in Granada, Spain

places.name: Monasterio de Nuestra Se√±ora de la Asunci√≥n "La Cartuja"

reviews.text: Building is really nice with one of the most beautiful art work, historical artwork is also displayed, have different rooms with all the details of Christian history.
This is one of the stops on the site seeing bus. Most people make the mistake of not getting off and missing this little gem hidden away. Very impressive church and only ‚Ç¨6

I went before it was open so I could only see the outside.

I has a beautiful small park at th door and some souvenir shops. What got my attention was the statue on top of the front door which has baby head and hands (see pictures for details). Not sure if on purpose or if it was replaced somewhere in time. Would love to hear about the backstory on this.

places.address: P.¬∫ de Cartuja, s/n, Beiro, 18011 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: Nestled atop a small mountain, the Ermita de San Miguel Alto is a charming historic church that offers breathtaking panoramic views of Granada and the iconic Alhambra. While it may not be as easily accessible as other viewpoints, the effort to reach this serene spot is well worth it for those who appreciate stunning photography opportunities. The hike can be challenging, but once you arrive, you'll be rewarded with an unparalleled bird's-eye view of the city and its surroundings.

sources.snippet: Hardly the ‚Äòbest kept secret‚Äô of the city anymore, the highest point in Granada can provide some truly awesome photographic opportunities of the Alhambra and the surrounding city, but you certainly have to be willing to work for it. To get here, you essentially need to clamber up a small mountain ‚Äì the co-ordinates you need to plug into google maps will be for ‚ÄòErmita De San Miguel Alto,‚Äô and you can reach it after visiting San Nicolas viewpoint. Word of warning, this site is purportedly the location for a religious pilgrimage that occurs ever year in late September, so probably avoid it then.
sources.shortName: Best Places in Granada to Photograph the Alhambra

sources.snippet: If you keep wondering where to shot the best photos of Granada, this is one of our favorite places üòç. Not all visitors come here, as it is located in the highest part of the Albaic√≠n, offering spectacular views of the Alhambra, the Albaic√≠n and the surroundings of the city. That is why it is a popular place to watch the sunset, when the different tones of the sky mix with the night lights that turn on in the city.
sources.shortName: 12 Great photo spots in Granada üì∏, What's your favorite?

sources.snippet: Ermita de San Miguel Alto is another viewing place that was recommended to me but sadly I didn‚Äôt get the chance to go myself. It‚Äôs located quite far away from the city centre and is very close to Sacromonte. It might be worth combining a trip to Sacromonte Cave Museum (Museo Cuevas del Sacromonte) with a trip to see the view from here since the two are in the same region as each other.
sources.shortName: Where to Get the Best Alhambra Views and Photos in 2019

sources.snippet: Just a 15 minute walk from the Albayz√≠n yet seemingly a world away lies the Ermita de San Miguel Alto. This quaint little hermitage is perched on a quiet hillside overlooking the city. The quiet atmosphere and beautiful views make it a great spot for couples to enjoy a romantic moment together.
sources.shortName: 7 Spectacular Places to Watch the Sunset in Granada You Need to See

sources.snippet: This Mirador is quite the hike, but the view is so worth it!. You can get there by foot or by car. My favorite time to go was right before sunset, because when the sun sets, the lights turn on the Alhambra, and you can get a sick shot like this one (pictured above)!
sources.shortName: The Best Photo Spots in Granada, Spain

places.name: Ermita de San Miguel Alto

reviews.text: Lovely peaceful spot, pretty steepy for some, so it never gets too crowded. Views of the Alhambra and the city are spectacular.

Come here!! I woke up super early in the morning and made my way up to the church. The view was amazing. Watching the sunrise slowly hit the city made for a mesmerizing memory. Watching the city wake up and hearing the animals made it very peaceful. Great spot for pictures. Sunrise or sunset would be your best bet.. It is a climb so know that...but we'll worth it

This is the place to go in Granada for the best views of all over the city. Arrive just an hour or so before the sun goes down. Take some drinks and some snacks and trek up the hill. It's well worth the effort. We stayed just as the sun went down and watched all the lights starting to come on in the city. Magical

places.address: C. Patio de la Alberca, 36, Albaic√≠n, 18010 Granada, Spain

places.generalDescription: The Alcazaba is a 13th-century military citadel located within the Alhambra complex in Granada. The name "Alcazaba" comes from the Arabic word for Citadel and it served as a strategic fortification with sweeping views from its main watchtower, Torre de la Vela. This ancient structure was used by Moorish rulers to oversee their territory and is characterized by its massive walls and old ramparts.

sources.snippet: The Alcazaba is often overlooked and overshadowed by the beauty of the intricately decorated palace with lush gardens, but for me, it was one of the highlights of the Alhambra visit. It is true, that the building is pretty simple and not much of the original courtyard was preserved ‚Äì but wait till you see the views!. The Alcazaba: Location
sources.shortName: 10+ Best Photography Locations in Granada: Expert Tips

sources.snippet: From its towers, you get nice views over Granada and to the Sierra Nevada mountains. Especially the views over the old city the Albaic√≠n quarter with all the white houses are nice.
sources.shortName: Best of Andalusia - A Photographer's Guide to Granada

places.name: Alcazaba

reviews.text:
This place is truly amazing. I can see why its on the National Geographic top 100 places. It is totally unique. This has to be the best example of a Moorish hilltop fortress there is and they started building at the Alcazaba in 1238!
The Alcazaba itself is an incredible fortress. If you go here, make sure you do the tower at the back. I notices a few tour guides bypassing this. The views from the top over Granada are amazing and should not be missed.
There is also so much here from the gardens and the Alcazaba tower to the Nazaries palace and all the nooks and crannies' between. There are also some remarkable treasures on exhibit. You can easily spend a few hours walking around in here.
We made a special trip from Malaga to visit and it was well worth it. This is one place you have to visit . I would recommend getting here early. We got here for 08:30 when it opened, which seems to be the perfect time.

Next to the Nasrid palace, you could explore this formidable well preserved fortress which was used to the residence for the guards. Climb up to the watch tower to take in some amazing view of the city and the mountains.

Truly a marvel of the old days, where arab invention was still a for the European development. Enjoy a 3 hour walk around the garden, castle and don't worry if you couldn't get the tickets for the Palacios Nazaries. You possibly won't have the energy to see all of it including the museums. Take it with a smile and have a great day!

places.generalDescription: Plaza Nueva de Granada, located at the base of the Alhambra in Spain, is a vibrant and historic square that has been a hub for social and cultural activities for many years. The bustling public space is surrounded by charming historic buildings, outdoor cafes, and shops, creating a lively atmosphere. Visitors can enjoy traditional Spanish food, decadent churros, or even pizza while taking in the view of the Alcazaba at the Alhambra.

sources.snippet: Plaza Nueva is a very nice and lively place located in the center of Granada, besides being a perfect place to take beautiful pictures, it also guarantees that there will always be something interesting and fun going on. It is also a place full of bars and entertainment areas, being the perfect place to stop and take a break if your night is being intense.
sources.shortName: What to see in Granada at night: your 7 best choices

places.name: Plaza Nueva de Granada

reviews.text: Starting and ending points to get anywhere. It's such a lovely place with its exquisite architecture, hidden treasure-like restaurants and small shops. The Christmas lights are beautiful and cheerful. The Christmas lights are beautiful and so romantic.
Granada is beautiful.  Lots to see and many places to hike to. Bring hiking poles
Incredible architecture and history.  The garden was very nice too.  Make sure to buy tickets 3 weeks in advance either for guided tour or for Nasrid Palace.
